title: 109_hr3506
content: The Act titled "Unsolved Civil Rights Crime Act" urges authorities to promptly investigate unsolved civil rights murders and allocate necessary resources for thorough investigations. The Act defines key terms like "Chief" and "criminal civil rights statutes," which include various sections of the United States Code related to civil rights violations. The Act defines key terms related to civil rights violations, including the Unsolved Crimes Section established under section 4. The Act defines key terms related to civil rights violations, including the establishment of the Unsolved Crimes Section under section 4. The Civil Rights Division of the Department of Justice has an Unsolved Crimes Section headed by a Chief responsible for investigating and prosecuting violations of criminal civil rights statutes that occurred before December 31, 1969 and resulted in a death. The Chief consults with State or local officials regarding cases involving alleged practices prohibited by law. Complaints violating criminal civil rights statutes are referred to the Criminal Section of the Civil Rights Division. The Chief conducts an annual study. The Chief annually conducts a study to determine cases with sufficient evidence for prosecution of criminal civil rights violations. A report is submitted to Congress by September 30 each year, including cases with insufficient evidence for prosecution. $5,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2006 to carry out this section. The Chief conducts an annual study to identify cases for prosecution of civil rights violations. $5,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2006 and subsequent years for this purpose, with additional appropriations provided.
